FuncDef: The display ospfv3 peer command displays specified OSPFv3 neighbors.
CLIs: display ospfv3 [ <process-id> ] [ area { <area-id> | <area-id> } ] peer [ { <neighbor-id> | hostname <hostnamestr> } | <interfaceName> | <interfaceType> <interfaceNum> ] [ verbose ]
display ospfv3 [ <process-id> ] [ area { <area-id> | <area-id> } ] peer [ <neighbor-id> | <interfaceName> | <interfaceType> <interfaceNum> ] resolve-hostname [ verbose ]

ParaDef.Info:
Specifies an OSPFv3 process ID.
The value is an integer ranging from 1 to 4294967295.

Specifies an area ID.
The value can be a decimal integer or in the IPv4 address format. The integer ranges from 0 to 4294967295.

Specifies router ID of a neighbor.
The value is in dotted decimal notation.

Specifies a dynamic hostname.
The value is a string of 1 to 255 characters.

Indicates the type of an interface.
-

Indicates the number of an interface.
The value is a string of 1 to 63 case-sensitive characters, spaces not supported.

Displays detailed information of neighbors of each area.
-

Displays the brief information about the last neighbor that goes Down in an OSPFv3 process. A maximum of the last ten neighbors that go Down can be displayed for each process.
-

Displays information about resolved dynamic hostnames.
-

Examples: Neighbor ID     Pri   State           Dead Time   Interface                Instance ID
In the area 0.0.0.1 via interface GE1/0/0
Immediate Reason    : Neighbor Down Due to AdjOK?
Primary Reason      : Router State Change from DR or BDR to DROTHER
Immediate Reason    : Neighbor Down Due to Kill Neighbor
Neighbor ID   Pri   State   Dead Time  Interface   Instance ID
Neighbor ID      Pri State            Dead Time  Interface          Instance ID
ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
The command output can display information about OSPFv3 neighbors, and help you troubleshoot OSPFv3 faults, verify the configurations of OSPFv3 neighbors, and check whether the neighbor performs Graceful Restart (GR).
